published_attributes.title: About the course
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Target Audience

This course is designed to use for:

  • technical people who want to update & upgrade their Serverless basic knowledge by doing challenging exercises
  • non-technical people who want to learn more about this doctrine and understand how we can use it in real world

The structure of the course

This course consists of 8 mini lessons - short slides with explanation of each essential part of Serverless methodology. In the 8th slide you can find attachment (link) to our Serverless challenges made in tech-agnostic way - feel free to rock them and check yourself about usage of this tech.

fyi. In any case of issues you can ask a question on #serverless channel

published_attributes.title: Serverless doctrine
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Serverless computing is a method of providing backend services on an as-used basis. A serverless provider allows users to write and deploy code without the hassle of worrying about the underlying infrastructure. A company that gets backend services from a serverless vendor is charged based on their computation and do not have to reserve and pay for a fixed amount of bandwidth or number of servers, as the service is auto-scaling. Note that despite the name serverless, physical servers are still used but developers do not need to be aware of them. ~cloudflare

Long story short - Serverless allows us to build applications in agile way manner - it means that we want to develop things by using already existing blocks of services/features provided by cloud or other 3rd party tools.

published_attributes.title: Serverless from AWS tech perspective
published_attributes.serialized_body:
SLS from tech perspective its just a proxy between us - developers and cloud/service provider, ie. Serverless for AWS in the end generated CloudFormation template which is core orchestrator or creator of services and solutions on Amazon.

Main "glue" technology when it comes to AWS its a Lambda service, its a compute service for delivering business logic, connecting together other Amazon services or delegating ops/monitoring work. (See AWS video below!)

We need to mention that Lambda gives you a huugge amount of options and configuration possibilities (ie. runtime environment - Node.js is most common or memory amount). There is also a way of use ready-to-use blueprints, container apps & consuming solutions from Serverless repository.

(Log into ur AWS account and go into Lambda service)

  • fun fact: year ago there was only scratch option & blueprint on Node.js version 6 to 8, and now, as you can see it grows so fast as a Lambdas-AWS platform

published_attributes.title: Neo, there is "red pill" and "blue pill"
published_attributes.serialized_body:
There is always other options.

  • Yes, thats true - few years ago when Serverless starting his journey there was only few small startups who started thing about it seriously. One of them grows ultra-fast thanks to SLS approach, they created a framework which brings to them a lot of fame and of course money. Obviously they named their precious - Serverless
  • But! there were always other options to pick from! Just after huge Serverless framework success AWS woke up and asks their selfs: "Hmm, maybe we should do the same thing but in different way?" - well, they did and its was named AWS CDK (Cloud Development Kit), the Serverless from AWS - the same but different! because it allows you to use ie. Typescript as a ops language.

  • The last thing that we need to consider as a "king" of cloud templates its a Terraform, we don't want to go deeply under the implementations and features that it gives, I just want to say that it covers almost all clouds and options of cloud development that you can imagine

TL'DR:

  • Serverless, AWS CDK, Terraform = yaml stack templates -> transformed to cloudformation

published_attributes.title: How to test clouds?
published_attributes.serialized_body:
The biggest issue and pain point of Serverless its a testing...

There were a lot of experiments when it comes to trying copy cloud on your local machine to do some development tests. After 2 years of trying different approach developers from the Serverless community agreed that on SLS doctrine we should focus mostly on Unit testing, and that's how this pyramid was created:

  • 1st. Focus on unit tests - cover all fundamental logic handler features that you can
  • 2nd. Check your services integration and collaboration between them by using dedicated developer environment on cloud or/and ie. Localstack tool for mocking core AWS services on your machine

published_attributes.title: Lets make hands dirty! part 1/2
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Well, this is it - the end of theory. The biggest advantage of Serverless it a "easy-use" approach, it means that if we want to understand it, we need to try it.

To summarise our knowledge about Serverless-AWS infrastructure I pasting in here image of basic SLS application on Amazon.

  • there is always a good practise to use ie. API Gateway before lambda to manage user load and control HTTP/WS connections to the Lambdas
  • S3 - managing static/object content
  • Lambda - our glue and logic handler
  • Dynamo - DynamoDB database, NoSQL, high performance db dedicated dynamic Serverless solutions
  • STS - Token service for managing token access to AWS
  • Cognito - Identity service for user authentication

Remember that every Serverless approach that you use will give you an option to drop your stack whenever you need, so don't worry about searching things that you develop on ie. AWS and forgot to delete after testing.
